awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Regenerable Adsorbent Filter for Water Purification
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact / commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to offer a low-cost novel filter to purify water with higher effectiveness and superior performance than currently available technologies such as carbon filters. The global water scarcity, including some parts of the US such as the southwest, has led to a strong need for efficient technologies to purify wastewater for direct or indirect potable reuse. Recently, there has been growing concerns over emerging contaminants such as perfluorinated compounds (PFCs e.g. PFOA and PFOS) in surface and groundwater. These PFCs are being found at many groundwater sites and in drinking water wells affected by PFCs. Current technologies are not efficient for the removal of PFCs from water, and there is an immediate need for new cost-effective treatment technologies. To address this unfulfilled need, this project seeks to develop a low cost, reusable filter unit for water purification to remove emerging contaminants such as PFCs. The technology is expected to be used by entities conducting industrial wastewater and groundwater treatment, and wastewater utilities that have a focus on water reuse. 

The objectives of this Phase II research project are to develop a prototype water filter,  test and optimize it for the removal of emerging contaminants with a focus on PFCs. Specifically, the project will focus on: (1) optimization of the adsorbent performance and synthesis method; and scale-up of the synthesis method for bulk production of filter media; (2) optimization of the filter regeneration process; and (3) design, construct, and test a prototype unit of the technology; and determine the process cost. The work will confirm the effectiveness of the filter in removing the target contaminants as well as the effectiveness of the regeneration process to reuse the filter. The PFC contaminants will be first removed from the water and then destroyed. The overall performance of the technology will also be evaluated and compared with other available technologies to determine its cost-effectiveness.

por.por_cntn:
There are many locations in the world, including the US, where water quality can be harmful to human health and the environment. It is essential to remove harmful pollutants so that the water could be used for its intended purpose.  A new class of water pollutants, known as per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) have been reported to be present in groundwater, surface water and treated wastewater effluent. PFAS have drawn significant attention in the media due to their ubiquitous presence and adverse health effects. PFAS contain strong carbon–fluorine bonds, which makes them one of the most stable compounds in the environment. They have been used as surfactants, emulsifiers, in fire-fighting foams, and surface coatings. The US EPA has a drinking water health advisory of 70 ng/L (parts per trillion) combined for two major PFAS chemicals (perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS).  There is a need to develop cost efficient technologies for water purification.

 

Amriton LLC is developing a low cost, regenerable and reusable water filter for the removal of per and poly fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and other contaminants from water. The primary goal of this SBIR project was to enhance the adsorbent synthesis method for its large-scale production and commercialization, optimize the adsorbent material for enhanced PFAS removal, optimize the filter regeneration process, evaluate the destruction of PFAS, and test a lab-scale prototype unit in the laboratory. We have developed a very efficient filter adsorbent material by optimizing the chemistry, synthesis conditions and support materials. The developed products show very high removal of both long chain and short chain PFAS. We can produce robust, polymer coated adsorbent in bulk quantity at room temperature and in one reactor (practical, scalable method).  The simple method for adsorbent synthesis can be used to coat sand and other base materials including fibers. Once the filter material is exhausted with PFAS, it is regenerated for reuse. The regeneration process was developed by considering a variety of regenerant solutions to remove PFAS from the filter material. PFAS removed from the adsorbent by the regenerant solution, can be efficiently destroyed using ultrasound and electrooxidation processes.  The technology was tested in column filters by pumping PFAS contaminated water through the filters. The filter can operate for weeks to remove PFAS from water.    

 

Amriton LLC is seeking partners for further optimization, field testing, and commercialization of the technology. The reusable water filter could be used for the removal and follow-on destruction of PFAS and other pollutants from groundwater and industrial wastewater. It offers an environmentally sustainable and potentially low-cost solution applicable at many industrial sites and contaminated groundwater sites.
